justification: “The core of CPT contains three main parameters, namely: (1) probability weighting (0 < γ < 5)…”.  This sentence states that the probability-weighting construct is operationalised by the γ parameter in Cumulative Prospect Theory.
The same passage lists “risk sensitivity (0 < α < 5)” as a core CPT parameter, showing that the α parameter is used to quantify individual risk sensitivity.
The CPT overview notes “loss sensitivity (0 < λ < 10)” and later explains that λ>1 captures loss aversion, indicating λ is the measure of the loss-sensitivity construct.

In describing the RL-CPT learning rule the authors write: “α⁺ (0 < α⁺ < 1) and α⁻ (0 < α⁻ < 1) are learning rates for positive and negative prediction errors, respectively,” identifying α⁺ as the metric for updating after positive errors.
The same sentence specifies α⁻ as the learning rate governing updates after negative prediction errors, thereby measuring sensitivity to negative prediction errors.

measured_by: Memory decay rate (1 − A) in IB-CPT
justification: When introducing the instance-based memory model, the paper defines “(1 − A) is a memory trace decay rate,” linking this parameter to the construct of memory decay during experience.

In the probabilistic choice rule section the authors note: “The choice sensitivity parameter (0 < β < ∞) controls how deterministically (larger β) versus randomly (smaller β) an individual makes choices,” indicating β operationalises the construct of choice determinism.
